definitions: use or put something or someone in place of another thing or person
temporarily perform the duties or fill the position of someone else
examples: The chef decided to substitute olive oil for butter in the recipe
You can substitute honey for sugar in most baking recipes
Sarah will substitute for the teacher while she recovers from surgery
The backup goalkeeper had to substitute when the starter got injured

definitions: add written translations or captions at the bottom of a movie or television screen
examples: The film studio decided to subtitle the movie in twelve different languages
We need to subtitle this documentary before the international film festival

definitions: take away a number or amount from another number to calculate the difference
examples: Children learn to subtract numbers in their first grade math class
You need to subtract the discount from the original price

definitions: damage or weaken something established especially a system of power or authority from within
examples: The spy attempted to subvert the government through secret propaganda campaigns
Hackers tried to subvert the company's security systems with malicious code

definitions: fail to resist pressure temptation or a negative force and yield to it
die from the effects of a disease injury or other destructive force
examples: After hours of negotiation she finally succumbed to their demands
He promised himself he wouldn't succumb to peer pressure again
The patient succumbed to his injuries despite the doctors' best efforts
Many plants succumb to frost during the harsh winter months

definitions: remove liquid gas or small objects using the force of air or water being pulled
examples: The dentist used a tool to suction saliva during the procedure
The vacuum cleaner will suction dirt from deep within the carpet

definitions: be enough or adequate to meet a particular need or requirement without excess
examples: A simple thank you note will suffice for the small gift
Two cups of flour should suffice for this cake recipe

definitions: attach a letter or group of letters to the end of a word
examples: You can suffix '-ing' to many verbs to create present participles
The programmer decided to suffix all test files with '_test'

definitions: kill or harm someone by preventing them from breathing or getting enough oxygen
make someone feel trapped overwhelmed or unable to develop freely in a situation
examples: Smoke from the fire can suffocate people trapped inside buildings
Never cover a baby's face as it could suffocate the child
Her controlling behavior began to suffocate him in the relationship
Too many rules and regulations can suffocate creativity in the workplace

definitions: damage or tarnish the good reputation character or purity of someone or something
examples: The scandal threatened to sully the company's hundred-year-old reputation
He refused to sully his family name with dishonest business practices

definitions: give a brief statement of the main points of something longer or more detailed
examples: The teacher asked students to summarize the chapter in one paragraph
Can you summarize the meeting for those who couldn't attend yesterday

definitions: order someone to come to a place or appear before an authority figure
make an effort to produce a quality or feeling from within oneself when needed
examples: The judge will summon the witness to appear in court next week
The principal summoned the students to her office immediately
She had to summon all her courage to speak in public
He tried to summon the strength to finish the marathon

definitions: cause skin to become red painful and damaged from too much exposure to sunlight
examples: Fair-skinned people sunburn easily without proper sunscreen protection
I forgot to reapply lotion and sunburned my shoulders at the beach

definitions: split apart or separate something especially with great force or violence
examples: The earthquake threatened to sunder the bridge into two pieces
Years of conflict finally sundered their once close friendship

definitions: eat the evening meal especially in a relaxed or informal way
examples: The family would sup together every night at six o'clock
We plan to sup at the local tavern after work

definitions: take the place of something older or less effective by being more modern or suitable
examples: Email has largely superseded traditional letter writing in business communication
The new safety regulations will supersede all previous workplace guidelines

definitions: watch and direct the work activities or performance of employees or a process to ensure quality
examples: She was hired to supervise the construction project from start to finish
Parents should supervise young children when they play near water

definitions: replace someone or something by force cunning or strategy often in an underhanded way
examples: The younger executive tried to supplant his boss through office politics
Digital cameras have supplanted film cameras in the photography market

definitions: make something soft flexible and able to bend easily without breaking or cracking
examples: Regular stretching will supple your muscles and prevent injury
Use leather conditioner to supple the stiff material of new boots

definitions: add something extra to enhance improve or complete something that may be lacking
examples: Many students supplement their income by working part-time jobs
The doctor advised her to supplement her diet with vitamin tablets

definitions: prevent something from being expressed shown or made public especially feelings or information
forcibly put an end to activities opposition or rebellion using authority or power
examples: He tried to suppress his laughter during the serious meeting
The government attempted to suppress news about the protest
The military was sent to suppress the uprising in the region
The new medication helps suppress allergy symptoms effectively

definitions: add an extra charge or fee on top of the usual cost or price
examples: The airline will surcharge passengers for checking bags over fifty pounds
Hotels often surcharge guests for using the minibar in their rooms

definitions: ride on ocean waves while standing or lying on a special board
casually browse or search through websites television channels or other media content
examples: They wake up early every morning to surf before work
She learned to surf during her vacation in Hawaii
Teenagers often surf the internet for hours looking at social media
He likes to surf different channels when nothing good is on

definitions: ride ocean waves while balancing on a long flat board designed for surfing
examples: Professional surfers can surfboard even the most challenging waves
She loves to surfboard at her local beach every weekend

definitions: move forward suddenly and powerfully like a wave or crowd of people
increase suddenly and dramatically in amount intensity or strength
examples: The crowd began to surge toward the stage when the band appeared
Waves surge against the rocky cliffs during the storm
Electricity demand will surge during the summer heat wave
Her emotions surged as she read the heartfelt letter

definitions: suppose or assume something is true without having definite proof or evidence
examples: From his nervous behavior we can surmise he knows more than he admits
Scientists surmise that the ancient structure served a religious purpose

definitions: exceed or go beyond something in amount degree or quality becoming greater or better
examples: This year's sales figures surpass all our previous records
Her performance continues to surpass everyone's expectations

definitions: stop fighting and admit defeat by giving control to an enemy or opponent
stop resisting something and allow yourself to be controlled by a feeling or influence
examples: The army had no choice but to surrender after running out of supplies
The suspect decided to surrender to police after a brief chase
She finally surrendered to her exhaustion and went to bed
Don't surrender to negative thoughts when facing challenges

definitions: join the edges of a wound or surgical cut by sewing with medical thread
examples: The surgeon will suture the incision after removing the appendix
The nurse learned how to properly suture different types of wounds

definitions: clean or wipe something using a small piece of absorbent material
collect a sample from a surface or body part using a cotton-tipped stick
examples: The sailor had to swab the deck every morning before breakfast
Nurses swab the injection site with alcohol before giving shots
The doctor will swab your throat to test for strep infection
Crime scene investigators swab surfaces to collect DNA evidence

definitions: walk in a very confident way with exaggerated movements to show off
examples: The champion boxer would swag into the ring before each fight
Teenagers often swag down the hallway trying to look cool

definitions: walk or behave in a very confident and arrogant way intended to impress others
examples: The bully would swagger around the playground intimidating younger kids
He tends to swagger after winning any competition

definitions: flood or overwhelm completely with too much of something especially water or work
cause to sink or become stuck in wet marshy ground
examples: Heavy rain threatened to swamp the small fishing boats
Don't swamp yourself with too many projects at once
The heavy truck began to swamp in the muddy wetland
Hikers must be careful not to swamp in marshy areas

definitions: move about in a leisurely aimless way often appearing carefree or showing off
examples: She likes to swan around the office chatting instead of working
Rich tourists swan about the resort without any schedule

definitions: display wealth possessions or achievements in an ostentatious way to impress others
examples: He loves to swank about his expensive car collection
She would swank her designer clothes at every opportunity

definitions: give something and receive something else in return especially things of similar value
examples: The children decided to swap their lunch sandwiches
Would you like to swap seats so you can see better

definitions: move somewhere in large numbers like insects flying or people walking together
crowd into or around a place in large numbers filling it completely
examples: Bees swarm around their hive protecting the queen
Tourists swarm to the beach during summer vacation
Fans began to swarm the stadium gates before the concert
Reporters swarm around celebrities at red carpet events

definitions: cause water or liquid to move around noisily splashing against something
examples: Waves swash against the side of the boat during storms
Children love to swash water around in the bathtub

definitions: hit something quickly and sharply especially a flying insect with hand or object
examples: She tried to swat the mosquito buzzing around her head
The cat would swat at anything that moved past its paws

definitions: wrap someone or something in several layers of fabric or bandages
examples: The nurse will swathe the burn victim in sterile gauze
Ancient Egyptians would swathe mummies in linen strips

definitions: move slowly or rhythmically backward and forward or from side to side
influence or change someone's opinion decision or actions through gentle persuasion
examples: Palm trees sway gently in the tropical breeze
The tall building began to sway during the earthquake
His passionate speech managed to sway many undecided voters
Don't let emotions sway your judgment in important decisions

definitions: become larger or rounder in size especially from internal pressure or fluid
rise and fall in long rolling movements like ocean waves
examples: Her ankle began to swell after she twisted it playing soccer
Wood tends to swell when exposed to moisture
The ocean would swell dramatically during the approaching storm
The music began to swell to a dramatic crescendo

definitions: change direction suddenly and sharply especially while driving to avoid hitting something
examples: The driver had to swerve to avoid hitting the deer
The cyclist swerved into traffic without looking

definitions: use deception or fraud to cheat someone out of money or possessions
examples: The con artist tried to swindle elderly people out of their savings
Don't let smooth-talking salespeople swindle you into bad deals

definitions: hit or try to hit something with a sweeping sideways motion
steal something quickly and often carelessly in passing
pass a card through an electronic reader to process payment or gain access
examples: The bear would swipe at fish with its powerful paws
The cat likes to swipe at dangling strings
Someone tried to swipe my wallet in the crowded market
Kids would often swipe candy from the corner store
Please swipe your credit card to complete the purchase
Employees must swipe their badges to enter the building

definitions: move in a twisting or spiraling pattern or cause liquid to move this way
examples: Autumn leaves swirl in the wind outside my window
She likes to swirl cream into her morning coffee

definitions: move with or make a soft rustling or hissing sound through the air
examples: Her silk dress would swish as she walked down the hall
The horse's tail swished back and forth keeping flies away

definitions: turn around a central point or axis while remaining in the same place
examples: Office chairs swivel so workers can reach different areas
The security camera can swivel to monitor the entire room

definitions: faint or lose consciousness especially from extreme emotion heat or shock
be overcome with extreme delight admiration or romantic attraction for someone
examples: Victorian ladies would swoon when their corsets were too tight
She nearly swooned from the heat at the outdoor wedding
Teenage fans swoon whenever the pop star appears on stage
He tends to swoon over every romantic movie he watches
